turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: Kat Ellis! We live two hundred miles away from each other but I have to fly all the way to London to see you. You havent visited me once in D.C. Where the hell have you been? I have gynecologists that call more often.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: You have more than one gynecologist?

turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: Sure. Youve got to play them against each other. Otherwise they think youre easy.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: You didnt have to do that.

turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: I wasnt saving you from him. I was saving you from yourself.

turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: Whats he do anyway?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Therapist.

turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: Like fifteen.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Dad made me go over and apologize the next day.

turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: Oh, no. He told you.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: You knew?

turns.speaker: TJ
turns.text: Im so sorry.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Hey, Sal.

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: I heard you were back in town, kitty cat. Youre here for the highland flings, I bet.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: I get all the glamour jobs.

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: The one I made for you is the cherries. You hang onto it or give it back?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Give it back? Are you nuts?

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: You pawned it.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Not exactly. I wear it.  On my right hand. And only rarely.

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: You want I nut him in the boat?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Yes? No. What?  Save the patter for the tourists.

turns.speaker: SAL
turns.text: You want me to let him in?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Of course, dont be silly.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Dad!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Hi, kiddo.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Meet Nick.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Thats not true. We checked for leaks a few years back.  Good morning.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Ahoy!

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: So whyd you let him go?

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Its complicated, Dad.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Oh, well, then. It probably wont work out.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Then for once in your life, do something for yourself.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Im worried. Amys not good at drinking. She gets sooo drunk sooo fast. Does free alcohol get you less drunk or more drunker?  Is it drunker or drunker-er?

turns.speaker: WOODY
turns.text: Just drunk enough.

turns.speaker: WOODY
turns.text: Not yet...

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: ...but its getting there. 

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: I thought you were living in San Francisco. Or was it Nepal?

turns.speaker: WOODY
turns.text: Close. Sydney. Turns out, I missed the rain.

turns.speaker: WOODY
turns.text: I always wondered what happened with us.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: I havent thought about that in years.

turns.speaker: KAT
turns.text: Shes drunk. -er than me. But I didnt really dump you, did I?

turns.speaker: WOODY
turns.text: Hard.

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Im guessing MacCallum, 18 years.  Neat, with a water-back.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Is there any other way to take it?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I am now, sir.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: At least somebodys using the damn thing.  I was gonna fix her up but we took one trip and the kids fought so much, we never launched her again.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: What is it you do again?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: What would you say if I told you I was a member of an elite task force employed to safeguard our nations most precious resource: your daughter.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: What do you say to that?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: I say that feeling compelled to do the opposite of your parents is as enslaving as emulating them.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Best thing about being a dad is when your kid starts kicking your ass--

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: --and The ass of The man who adores her.

turns.speaker: VICTOR
turns.text: Hey, Sigmund, you think you could rustle up the bride and tell her to join the party?

turns.speaker: NICK
turns.text: Will do.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I just wanta wash my hand. It's got blood where I hurt it.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You don't live around here, do you?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: No, mam... I come from way back there. Me and my dog was tryin' to find my daddy and we got lost.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Is he here in Borderdale?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I don't know, he's in a prison camp.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Here, you put your hand under the water and I'll pump for you.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: My name is Camille -- Camille Johnson and I'm the Supervisor of this school. What's your name?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: David Lee Morgan. My dog's name is Sounder.  That feels better.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Let me see it...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You keep looking around, David. Don't you go to school?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Sometime, but not like this.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: It's a good thing your hand did not become infected -- how did you cut it like this?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Me and Sounder went to this prison camp to see my Daddy and the police guard runs us away and I fell on some glass.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Did your mother know you were going to see your father?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Uh huh...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: That does it...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Thank you, Miss Johnson.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I don't live far from here. You and your dog can come home with me and have yourself a hot meal and then we'll talk about how to get you back home.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You got a pretty house, Miss Johnson!

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I try...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: And you say all them people is dead now?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: That's right--

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: They lived a long time ago -- before you and I were born.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Where is Africa, Miss Johnson?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Here it is, right here.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: That's where we come from first?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: That's where we came from first.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: And the other people you told me 'bout, they is all colored folk?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Colored.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Don't you teach in your school 'bout folk who ain't dead?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Sure--

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Here's one by a man that's very much alive.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What's his name?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Dr. William E. B. Dubois.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What he talk 'bout?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Why don't you sit and I'll read you something he said.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You're a friendly lady, Miss Johnson.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: And you're a tired little boy. I'll make up the cot and you must get some sleep.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What about Sounder?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: He'll get his place too -- now off with your clothes and into bed.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Now don't you think it's time you told me all about yourself?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I have a mother and her name is Rebecca -- My father's name is Nathan Lee Morgan, and...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Well, how did you like the class, David?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: It was the best thing I ever been to, Miss Johnson!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: ... So me and Sounder, ran right by the men that was the prisoners, and crawled under the fence! That's when I cut my hand on the glass. It hurt like mad! But I kept runnin', and then I didn't feel no more hurtin' till I stopped runnin'!  Why was that, Miss Johnson?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Because all you could think of was getting away from the guard.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Oh... . You right, that's all that was worryin' me right then...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You know, that was a good thing you did for Clarence, in class today. I believed his story, but I was afraid the other children wouldn't...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: He was real scared nobody would believe him -- I could tell, even when he first stood up.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You could? How?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I been like that myself, when I thought nobody was gonna believe me...  You wanna hear another story?!

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Not now, David, it's time for bed. You have a long trip ahead of you in the morning...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: What are you looking at, out there? There's nothing to see.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: My daddy likes to look into the dark, even when there ain't nothin to see -- it's what you hear he say.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You think about your father a lot, don't you?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes mam...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Well, you shouldn't worry about him too much, David.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What do I tell my mama when I get home? I didn't find him and that's what I wanted to do.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: But you did all you could, David. Not many little boys could've gone on such a journey as you did.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: But where is my daddy!?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: I can't answer that for you -- but it's no fault of your own that you don't know where your father is now. You tell me what you did that kept you from finding your father.  Come on, tell me...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Nothin'...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: And so you did your job, right?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, mam...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Whewwww! You sure keep my mind jumping, boy!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What do that mean?

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Means you keep me using my head, and that's good!

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: You know that the class is going to challenge your story, don't you, Clarence?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yes, Miss Johnson...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Go on...

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Me and my little sister, went down to the water hole, last Saturday--

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: How was your sister after you pulled her out of the water?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: She was dirty and wet...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Clarence, would you tell us a story that was not true, after telling us it was?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: No, Miss Johnson...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE
turns.text: Can you swim?

turns.speaker: CLARENCE
turns.text: Yes mam...

turns.speaker: CAMILLE'S VOICE OVER
turns.text: :--THE STRANGE ENDINGS OF NATURE THEY HAVE SEEN, MAY GIVE THE WORLD NEW POINTS OF VIEW AND MAKE THEIR LOVING, LIVING, AND DOING PRECIOUS TO ALL HUMAN...

turns.speaker: DAVID'S IMAGES
turns.text: :The night in the woods with his father and SOUNDER. The shouting and laughter after the baseball game --

turns.speaker: CAMILLE'S VOICE OVER
turns.text: :...HEARTS. AND TO THEMSELVES IN THESE DAYS THAT TRY THEIR SOULS...

turns.speaker: DAVID'S IMAGES
turns.text: :HE, JOSIE and EARL, running and playing in the field.

turns.speaker: CAMILLE'S VOICE OVER
turns.text: :...THE CHANCE TO SOAR IN THE DIM BLUE AIR ABOVE SMOKE IS TO THEIR...

turns.speaker: DAVID'S IMAGES
turns.text: :His visit with his father at the County Jail house --

turns.speaker: CAMILLE'S VOICE OVER
turns.text: :...FINER SPIRITS BOON AND GUERDON FOR WHAT THEY LOSE ON EARTH BY BEING BLACK.

turns.speaker: DAVID'S IMAGES
turns.text: :His mother, with her head thrown back, her eyes aglitter and laughing.

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I can't do it, Rita -- that's the policy here on colored prisoners, and I ain't about to change it, not even for a friend like you.

turns.speaker: MRS. BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: Charlie, just because a man and his family are colored, you--

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Now look, Rita, I don't make the rules -- you puttin' yourself on a limb, comin' here, askin' me to do a thing like this. And I be damn if I'm going to jeopardize my job because you are in love with a little colored boy!

turns.speaker: MRS. BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: But, Charlie --

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: NO! N-O, NO!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: I see you found what you was lookin' for.

turns.speaker: MRS. BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: I did look, Charlie, but I--

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: No buts, Rita!

turns.speaker: MRS. BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: Charlie, you have no legal right not to let this boy know where his father is! You hear that, you and this whole damn court house; what you are doing is wrong!

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: Don't tell me about what's wrong. You come into my office as a friend and steal city files! I could have you arrested for that -- and if you give out that information to anybody, that's exactly what I'm going to do -- and I'll tell everybody in this town how you got the information and who you got it for! You won't have a friend left in this county to bring you a piece of candy!

turns.speaker: MRS. BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: You would do that, wouldn't you?

turns.speaker: CHARLIE
turns.text: You getting the point, Mrs. Boatwright.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: There ain't no possums in this woods tonight, Daddy.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Looks that way, son. Guess the cold done drove most of 'em down to the big water country -- but if there's one left out here -- we gotta find him.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: It's cold, Daddy!

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Here, put my jacket over you.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: If anybody's to blame, it's me -- I oughta nailed him when I took that shot.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: It was too dark, Daddy.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Yeah. We better git back to house now.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, sir...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: You oughta be tired, too, Sounder. That possum shore whipped the hell outta you tonight!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: He beat you, too, Daddy, and you had a big ol' shootin' rifle.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Boy, you don't make funny with your daddy like that.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: David Lee...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, sir...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: You had a rough time out there tonight -- so you stay home from that school tomorrow.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I wanna go -- the trip don't bother me none.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: You learnin' anything at that school?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, sir -- I learn to write a little bit, and I can read a lot--

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Readin' must be somethin' powerful, huh, son?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, sir...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: When the fall comes in these parts, the Night moon runs away like a rabbit -- you could stay out here lookin' all night, and not see a thing out yonder.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: We goin' huntin' again tomorrow ?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Yep. I guess you must wonder why though, what with the luck we havin', but like I always say--

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: "You lose some of the time, what you always go afta, but you lose all the time what you don't go afta!"

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Now who says I didn't lay my mark on you, boy!

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Well, looka here...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Hi, Daddy...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Hi to you, son...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Mama is outside with Josie Mae and Earl.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: They is!? It shore is good to see you, boy!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: We didn't find Sounder yet.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: He'll show up one day.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Do you think he's dead, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Naww -- he'll come back to you, soon as his wounds heal. This cake shore is tasty, son.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: It's a shame they won't let 'em come in here. If I had the strength I'd knock down these damn walls -- if I could just git my arms 'round your mama right now -- is they on this side of us, son?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I think so...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Can you say what camp they gon' send you to, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: I don't know, son -- they won't tell us things like that -- but I don't want y'all to come here no more.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Why, Daddy; you won't be here?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Just do like I tell you -- I'll get word to you through the visitin' preacher.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What's wrong with your leg, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Got it hurt in a dynamite blast, son. The dirty dogs had no more use for me, so they let me have time off my sentence, and let me come home.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Son, that was some trip you went on...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Where was you, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: That musta been afta they sent me to this place call Clayburn. That was the hardest workin' camp they sent me to. The work was so hard, you had to look for somethin' to laugh about to keep from feelin' the whole pain in your body. Like one time, it was in the middle of the day, and there weren't no sun -- you hear that?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Where did the sun go to, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Into the clouds and behind the mountains.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What happened afta that?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: The rains started to come, and the prisoners were scared to run 'cause they had to wait for guards to round us up, and tell us when to move -- but we didn't mind the rain comin' 'cause it meant we would git a little rest -- we just stood there, watchin' the guards and they weapons get wet, and that made us all feel kinda good for a minute. I was laughin' all over inside -- a minute, that's all, but what a minute it was!

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: And me too, son! You shore done got to be such a big little man!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: We goin' huntin' again, Daddy !?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: You bet we is!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I cleaned and oiled all your stuff while you was gone...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Goodnight, Daddy...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Goodnight to you, son...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Daddy, you home now... that's all I want -- I don't want nothin' else...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Come here, son...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Mornin', son...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Mornin', Daddy...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Where's everybody?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: They gone to the field...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Guess I can't just lay here, then.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You feel alright today, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Great, son -- not like wakin' up in jail. For a minute or two, didn't quite know where I was, but when I saw your face lookin down on me, made me know right away the day was gonna be a good one, and it all belonged to me!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Daddy, when is we goin' huntin'?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Soon -- but it won't be too much huntin' you'll be doin','cordin' to a good little story your mama told me last night -- you'll be goin' away from here, won't you?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: I'm real proud of how you helped your mama to keep this place goin', David Lee.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Thank you, Daddy...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Wheeew! This is some hard work, but it beats goin' to jail.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You won't be goin' to jail again, will you, Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: No, son -- they'd have to kill me before I'd let 'em do that to me again!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You hurt, Daddy!?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: No, no, I'm all right, son... This damn leg just won't act right no more!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: From Miss Johnson --

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Well, ain't you gon' open and read it for us?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Dear David, if you are coming to school here, be sure to bring some warm clothes. The school term will begin September 8th, but it would be good for you to be here by the 4th or 5th of the month. I do hope everything is fine and you will be here. Give my "hello" to your family. Yours truly, Miss Camille Johnson...

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: September 4 -- how far away is that?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You just came back home, Daddy. I don't wanna leave right now -- I wanna stay home and be with you.

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: And I wanta be with you, too, but this school is somethin' that's good for you -- somethin you need, like good air to breathe, and I want you to have it, boy, and that's the way it's gonna be!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: But, Daddy, you need me here to help you in the field -- Daddy, your leg is hurt -- you can't work like you used to. Who's gonna help you!? Who's gonna do the work, Daddy?!

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Let me tell you somethin', boy! I don't care if both of my legs was cut off! I can do more work in that field, than you could in a hundred years!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I won't go, Daddy! I won't go!

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: Now wait justa minute! You don't tell me what you ain't gonna do! I tell you! I say, you goin' to that school, you goin'! You hear me!

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: I love you, son! Don't ever think I don't love you!  We gon' get to be friends?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, Daddy! Yes!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: You know somethin', Daddy?

turns.speaker: NATHAN LEE
turns.text: What's that, son?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I'm gon' miss this ol' raggedy place.

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: What's your daddy's name?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Nathan Lee Morgan...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Mister, can you visit anybody here?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Gotta wait 'til visitin' days.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: When's that?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Sunday...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Do you know my daddy, Nathan Lee Morgan?

turns.speaker: GUARD
turns.text: Never heard of 'im. We gotta lotta men here...

turns.speaker: MRS BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: David, you never cease to amaze me at how good you are in taking care of my garden.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: My father taught me...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Miss Boatwright --

turns.speaker: MRS BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: Yes, David...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Will you help me to find out what camp they sent my father to?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: See you tomorrow, Miss Boatwright.

turns.speaker: MRS BOATWRIGHT
turns.text: David!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes, ma'am...?

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: What's in there, David!?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Sausage and hambones!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: He eats all right -- his throat ain't scarred.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: Then why don't he holler like he usta?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: He will... Come on, git down and act like a possum.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: I don't look like no possum!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Act like one!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I guess I'll havta work harder to git him back like he usta be.

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: Why don't you try and git you a new dog?

turns.speaker: EARL
turns.text: Naw, I'm carryin' it!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Thank you, Josie Mae.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: David Lee, it's time for you to get to bed!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Goodnight.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Mama, there's hot meat on the stove!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: That's right!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Where did it come from, Mama?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Where all meat come from -- now git yourself washed up and be snappy about it -- you got six miles ahead of you to that school.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Ready to go, Mama!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Tuck that shirt in, David Lee.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You got two shirts on?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Yes mam...

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: When you get outta that school, you come right on back home, y'all gon' have to take this laundry work I done for Miss Boatwright today.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Who's winning, Mama?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Nobody yet -- it's all tied up.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: What do they do in the white churches, Mama?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Same as we -- they pray.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Who is they?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Children, come here...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Don't take my Daddy! Please don't take my Daddy!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: David, come back here!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: 'Bye, Mama...

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: 'Bye, son -- I won't be gone long.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Did you see Daddy?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No, son. We havta wait 'til the holiday comes -- anyway, they won't let womenfolk see their men no time.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Can I go when the holiday comes?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: You sure can, son...

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Any sign of Sounder?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: No mam -- I looked all over.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: I think maybe he was scraped on the head by that shot. I don't think he's dead -- just gone somewhere to heal himself.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: What is it, David Lee?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Listen, Mama...

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Poor creature...

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: He'll be all right, Mama. I'll make him all right.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Mama! Mama! Miss Boatwright, say she gon' help me find where Daddy is!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Good! But you don't have to tell the whole valley 'bout it! You'll get that woman in trouble!

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Can't sleep?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: No, ma'am...  Mama, I wanted Mrs. Boatwright to find out where Daddy is, so me and Sounder can go see him.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: So did I. I figured when the time got right, we could all take a day or two and walk up there, but it's not the kind of long trip for a child to take alone.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: I can do it, Mama -- you know that. In the Bible stories you read to us, everybody's always goin' on a long journey. Jacob goes into a strange land where his uncle is and he don't even know where he lives, but he finds him. Everybody finds what they supposed to find.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: But you'll be away from home for days -- what will you do when the dark comes, where will you sleep? I can't send you away from here like that!

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Mama, don't I always do what you say -- every time I go to the fields to plant the corn, to Miss Boatwright's and the woods -- you tell me what to do and I do it, and you don't worry.

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: No, I don't and I oughtn't not to after the way you've taken over since they took him away -- and I would like for you to see 'im so you can come back and tell me about 'im.  The field's all planted, so I guess I can spare you for a little while. When do you wanta leave?

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Can I go day after tomorrow?

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Yes, son. You better get back to bed.

turns.speaker: DAVID LEE
turns.text: Good night, Mama...

turns.speaker: REBECCA
turns.text: Good night...
